incident_updates.body: Our operations and engineering teams have completed recovery work on the remaining environments for the US-3 region.

We have detected lingering issues for some environments on the US-3 region from the previous incident earlier today, which we are actively working to resolve.

Some environments may still not be responding to requests, and may still have failing deploy activities. Please open an urgent support ticket if your site on the US-3 region is not responding to requests, or if production deploy activities are failing.

These issues and outages do not impact Dedicated Enterprise Clusters.
This incident has been resolved
All projects have been recovered and we are monitoring the region.
We are currently recovering the affected projects. Some are already back up and operational.

We have detected an issue affecting service on the US-3 region. We are currently working to restore service.

This issue affects multiple production sites as well as development environments. Access to your site, project UI as well as Git and SSH access may be affected.

This outage does not affect Dedicated Enterprise Clusters.

We will update you as soon as we have further information.

**Overview**

On March 2nd, at 20:23 UTC an incident was declared for the us-2 region. On-call engineers began receiving alerts for multiple sites down and immediately began an investigation.

**What Happened**

A maintenance operation applied to the storage layer unintentionally resulted in degraded performance for most of the grid hosts in the region. The purpose of the maintenance was to improve the storage layer by switching to an upgraded back end but the migration to this new system resulted in elevated CPU resource consumption leading to a major performance impact on any environment running on one of these affected hosts.

**Resolution**

In order to mitigate the impact of the incident, additional storage layer resources were provisioned and deployed to the region. The migration was able to continue as planned and grid hosts began to recover as expected.

**Impact**

We have paused this same maintenance across all regions to assess how to safely move forward.

This incident has been resolved.

We have released a fix for the storage backend and now region US-2 should function as expected.
Please create support ticket for further assistance if needed.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
We have identified the cause as related to our storage backend. We are issuing a fix now and will provide updates soon.
We are aware of some projects within the US-2 region that are experiencing a variety of issues. We are currently investigating and will provide updates when we have more information.

We are still actively investigating the incident root cause.
Currently affected environment actions: deployment, redeploys, creation, deletion, and activation. Please refrain from using them while the incident is ongoing.

Our cloud infrastructure provider identified a recent WAN update as the likely underlying cause, and have taken steps to roll back this update. Our monitoring shows signs of recovery across multiple regions and services, and we are continuing to actively monitor the situation.

**Overview**

On July 21st, at 03:11 UTC, our On-call engineers began receiving alerts for multiple sites down on the AU and CA-1 and immediately began an investigation. They verified that environments and console requests were timing out.

**What Happened**

A sudden influx of traffic was identified from several malicious sources. This caused the edge services in the AU and CA-1 regions to experience extremely high load which resulted in connectivity issues with customer environments and consoles.Our engineers confirmed the origin of the attack and took action to mitigate the malicious traffic. Once mitigations were completed, site monitoring reported that the sites were accessible again.

**Resolution**

We are implementing additional methods to minimise the impacts of this type of attack.

**Impact**

The incident prevented access to all projects in the AU and CA-1 regions. Once mitigations were in place, sites immediately became accessible again and service was restored to normal. Individual projects experienced unavailability of up to one hour at most. The total length of the incident, including the monitoring period, lasted for 90 minutes.
This incident has been resolved.
All alerts are now showing as resolved. We are continuing to monitor these regions.
Sites are recovering. We are continuing to work on resolving this outage.
We are actively working to resolve this issue.

We have detected an issue affecting service on the au.platform.sh and ca-1.platform.sh regions. We are currently working to restore service.

This issue affects multiple production sites as well as development environments. Access to your site, project UI as well as Git and SSH access may be affected.

This outage does not affect Dedicated Enterprise Clusters.

We will update you as soon as we have further information.

incidents.name: Console and CLI Outage Across all Regions

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.
We are currently investigating an outage impacting the Console and CLI across all regions. Production sites are still serving requests, but Console and CLI access is currently degraded.

**Overview**

New Blackfire APM data was unavailable for up to 15 hours.

**What Happened**

Due to a code change made in early July to the APM consumer service, the disk space on the underlying infrastructure exceeded its estimated requirement resulting in a disk full event. This resulted in an inability to process data in a reasonable time in addition to some loss of monitoring data between 16 July 0540 UTC and 16 July 0940 UTC.

**Resolution**

* Additional disk storage was added to the volume.
* Additional disk monitoring and alerts have been added.
* A review of the recent code changes is underway to reduce the impact on disk storage.

**Impact**

During this incident customers dashboards did not display new data. Once the consumer was recovered, live data was ingested in realtime in parallel with the backlog and all available data was up-to-date after approximately 15 hours.
This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results. The backlog of messages are currently being processed.

We have detected an issue affecting Blackfire service. Our Operations team has been notified and is currently working to restore service. 

We will update you as soon as we have further information.

We are having some issues with our data pipeline. We are still receiving data from agents, but they are not processed anymore. Your APM dashboards have not been updated since July 15th 10PM UTC. We are working on resuming the processing. No data has been lost. Performance of applications running Blackfire agent is not affected

**Overview**

On July 11th, at 06:45 UTC, an incident was declared for the \(de-2\) region. Platform.sh monitoring detected a number of sites down alerts during the scheduled maintenance, https://status.platform.sh/incidents/vt4zmxmjqdlk - upon further investigation we determined the issue was due to multiple overloaded hosts. We provisioned additional hosts to alleviate the load and rebalanced the environments across these new hosts.

What Happened

The maintenance was performed on the orchestration layer, which included an update to our backup process. 

After the maintenance, we saw that this updated backup process caused a higher than expected load on an agent running on the hosts there by slowing down the recovery of sites. Plaform.sh technical teams have determined the root cause of high load on the agent, and a fix is being planned for roll-out in the near future.

**Impact**

The incident impacted both production and development environments. Most projects were recovered by 08:09 UTC, with a small portion of projects needing manual recovery by Platform.sh engineers. Observed downtime ranged from 30 minutes to 2 hours.
This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.

We have detected an issue affecting service on the DE2 region. This is related to the scheduled maintenance, https://status.platform.sh/incidents/vt4zmxmjqdlk and is causing longer outages than expected.

Our Operations team has been notified and is currently working to restore service. 

We will update you as soon as we have further information.

incidents.name: Composer: allow-plugins change causing application issues

incident_updates.body:
The composer change causing build to fail silently was fixed in release 2.3.9 (fixed by pull request https://github.com/composer/composer/pull/10920).

Builds will now fail with error `E: Error building project: composer could not be run.` instead of building without executing plugin.

We have seen an influx of support tickets regarding the recent plugin changes in composer.

https://github.com/composer/composer/commit/ac7a6e3326593c5a574e10aff3002a6e523ed982

This manifests as the following warning in your Platform.sh build log;

W: XXXX/XXXX contains a Composer plugin which is blocked by your allow-plugins config. You may add it to the list if you consider it safe. See https://getcomposer.org/allow-plugins
W: You can run "composer config --no-plugins allow-plugins.XXXX/XXXX [true|false]" to enable it (true) or keep it disabled and suppress this warning (false)

This warning requires you to update your composer.json file as per https://getcomposer.org/doc/06-config.md#allow-plugins

Please implement these changes and retest your builds. 

We are working with the composer team to ensure that these builds fail instead of build without the needed application plugins. 

https://github.com/composer/composer/issues/10912

**Overview**

On June 26th, at 08:36 UTC, an incident was declared for the \(fr-4\) region. Platform.sh monitoring detected a number of site down alerts and upon further investigation determined the issue was a result of maintenance being performed by the upstream service provider.

**What Happened**

The maintenance performed by the service provider required a reboot of several components in the region that caused production and development environments to become unavailable. The nature of this maintenance was related to routine security patches being rolled out across several hosts in the region.

After the reboot, several hosts did not recover as expected and required more intervention by Platform.sh engineers. The faulty hosts were replaced and projects were evacuated across to the good hosts for recovery to take place. A small percentage of projects did not recover as expected during the evacuation which resulted in a longer downtime for those said projects.

Platform.sh technical teams have fixed the bug that prevented hosts from recovering as expected and the same is being rolled out. Investigation on failures that occurred during evacuation are being carried out and will be fixed appropriately in future.

**Impact**

The incident impacted both production and development environments. Most projects were recovered by 11:53 UTC with a small portion of projects needing manual recovery by Platform.sh engineers. Observed downtime ranged from 60 minutes to 2 hours and 40 minutes.
This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.

We have detected an issue affecting service on the FR-4 region. Our Operations team has been notified and is currently working to restore service. Projects in the affected region may experience site outages.
We will update you as soon as we have further information.
Cloudflare has confirmed that this incident has been resolved.
Cloudflare have communicated that a fix has been implemented, we are monitoring the results and can see sites recovering in our monitoring system.

Support tickets can still be submitted via the console, but may not be available to view from certain locations.

We are still receiving all tickets submitted via the Platform.sh Console.

We are aware of issues with Cloudflare connectivity. Any sites using Cloudflare's services may be unavailable in some parts of the world. 

We will update you as soon as we have further information.

**Overview**

On June 20th, at 20:11 UTC, an incident was declared for the \(eu-4\) region. There was scheduled maintenance being performed that included a brief outage for every project however this outage lasted longer than expected.

Maintenance announcement: https://status.platform.sh/incidents/scsm9yy84sdy

**What Happened**

At 19:01 UTC, scheduled maintenance commenced on the region as planned. By 19:50 UTC reports of outages began to arrive. The central coordination layer on the region was affected and as a result several components had to be restarted to bring the services in the region back online. 

Further actions and procedural changes are being made to prevent maintenances from affecting the coordination layer.

**Impact**

The incident impacted all projects on the region. By 21:15 UTC most projects had returned to normal operating levels. The longest observed outage lasted for 1 hour and 30 minutes.
This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We have detected an issue affecting service for production sites on the EU-4 region. We are currently working to restore service.

**Overview**

On June 20th, at 09:24 UTC, an incident was declared for the \(eu-4\) region. Platform.sh monitoring detected a number of site down alerts and upon further investigation determined the issue was a result of gateway performance.

**What Happened**

At 09:08 UTC, monitoring alerts indicated a high volume of traffic entering the region. A mitigation plan to address it was quickly implemented. By 09:12 this traffic volume had been mitigated. We declared an incident to further review the issue and identify the root cause. Investigation determined a small number of sources being the cause of the traffic volume.

Platform.sh has plans in the roadmap to put in place appropriate rate limiting to prevent such traffic spikes from bringing down several sites in the region.

**Impact**

The incident was classified as a partial outage with most sites returning to normal operating levels by 09:17. The longest observed outage lasted a total of 14 minutes with most monitored sites only experiencing a 1 minute to 3 minute outage.
This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.

We have detected an issue affecting service on the EU-4 regions. Our Operations team has been notified and is currently working to restore service. Projects in this region may see timeouts or other outages on their production and development sites.

We will update you as soon as we have further information.

**Overview**

On June 10th, at 15:19 UTC, an incident was declared for the \(eu-4\) region. Platform.sh monitoring began to see an influx of site down alerts and upon further investigation discovered the issue was originating from the region's storage layer.

**What Happened**

This was a partial region outage affecting just a portion of hosted projects in the region.

The regions storage layer was degraded due to a component of this system becoming overwhelmed and then unavailable. Any project connected to this specific component would have experienced this outage. The service began a self healing process to remedy the failure and by 15:52 UTC this self healing had completed. A post incident investigation has identified the root cause of the component failure and a fix has been made.

After the recovery, not all production environments were able to begin serving traffic immediately and required manual intervention by Platform.sh support. Please note that projects that included a MySQL service were impacted by this situation. The MySQL containers did not correctly restart and a connection could not successfully be made to the database container. The support team then handled the necessary repairs on a case by case basis to restore the functionality to these impacted environments that still had not recovered automatically. 

This particular issue regarding the MySQL service has been remedied since this incident occurred. 

**Impact**

The incident was open for 4 hours and 40 minutes. Any project not running a MySQL service would have been restored by 15:52 UTC with an estimated outage of 48 minutes. Any project utilizing a MySQL service would have had a various length of outage time that lasted at a minimum of 48 minutes.
The incident has been resolved.  If you continue to have issues, please open a new support ticket.

We've implemented a fix and recovered all sites in the region.  We're currently monitoring things.

If you are still seeing issues, please open a support ticket.
We are continuing to work on a fix for this issue.
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.

We have detected an issue affecting service on the EU-4 regions. Our Operations team has been notified and is currently working to restore service. Projects in this region may see timeouts or other outages on their production and development sites.

We will update you as soon as we have further information.

**Overview**

On May 18th, at 11:33 UTC, an incident was declared for the \(us-2\) region. Earlier that day, scheduled maintenance was performed on the region which led to the unavailability of both production and development environments. This was a partial outage event which only impacted a small portion of projects hosted in the us-2 region.

**What Happened**

The Platform.sh support team began receiving alerts for several monitored sites which prompted an immediate investigation. Earlier at 09:00 UTC, scheduled maintenance began and upon completion the impacted environments failed to come back online. The issue was identified and a patch has been rolled out to prevent this same issue from happening again in future maintenance for all regions.

**Impact**

Both production and development environments were impacted and remained unavailable throughout the incident for only the affected projects. 

The total outage lasted for 1 hour and 31 minutes.
This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.

We have detected an issue affecting service on the us-2 region. Our Operations team has been notified and is currently working to restore service. Projects on affected regions may experience site downs.
We will update you as soon as we have further information.
The upstream issues at Fastly have been resolved, and we have not observed any further errors.  If you are still seeing issues accessing your site, please open a support ticket.
We're no longer seeing TLS errors, and we're continuing to monitor the situation.

We are seeing intermittent TLS errors with our CDN partner, Fastly. 

Customer sites using the Fastly CDN may display TLS errors or fail to complete TLS handshakes.

For more information, see the Fastly service status: https://status.fastly.com/incidents/vmmf4rcmkhyz#
This incident has been resolved.

Our teams have concluded their work related to CVE-2022-29582. Affected parts of the infrastructure have been patched. That concludes this incident.

Platform.sh will continue to proactively investigate future CVE announcements as they arise.

This message is to inform you that Platform.sh is aware of the recently announced CVE-2022-29582 Linux kernel vulnerability. All teams have been actively working to determine the potential impact on Platform.sh systems as well as any necessary mitigation steps. We will be publishing further updates as the work progresses.

References:
https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2022-29582
https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2022-29582

**Overview**

On April 28th two incidents were declared for the EU region at 07:15 UTC and 12:45 UTC respectively. The incidents were both related and involved the Console UI and CLI becoming unavailable. 

All production and development environments remained online throughout the incident.

**What Happened**

The Platform.sh API experienced a failure to retrieve data from a backend service layer that failed because of memory scarcity.

**Resolution**

The API was recovered by increasing the memory allocation on the coordination service. A change has been implemented that improves the monitoring of this coordination service. Were continuing to investigate the unexpected increase in resources of this service.

**Impact**

The Console UI and CLI were intermittently unavailable between 07:00 UTC and 13:00 UTC.
This incident has been resolved.

We have detected an issue affecting service on the eu.platform.sh region. Our Operations team has been notified and is currently working to restore service.

Affected projects experience the following issues: the UI is not loading properly, and timeouts while using the CLI.

Production environment availability is unaffected.

incidents.name: Information regarding CVE-2022-21449, the Psychic Signatures in Java vulnerability

incident_updates.body:
Our teams have concluded their work related to CVE-2022-21499. As initially indicated, Platform.sh Java images were not susceptible to this vulnerability. Some service images were found to be potentially vulnerable, but as Platform.sh does not directly expose services to the Internet the susceptibility was already limited and we have no evidence of any compromise. For those service images, updated versions have been released. 

That concludes our work on this incident.

Platform.sh will continue to proactively investigate future CVE announcements as they arise.

This message is to inform you that Platform.sh is aware of the recently announced CVE-2022-21449 vulnerability and we are working to assess the impact. At this time, we have confirmed that Platform.sh Java images are unaffected. We are currently analyzing the vulnerability of other Java-based services.

We will update this page with more information as it becomes available.

References:

https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2022-21449

https://neilmadden.blog/2022/04/19/psychic-signatures-in-java/

**Overview**

On April 21st, at 23:24 UTC, an incident was declared for the \(us\) region. Earlier that day, scheduled maintenance was performed that introduced a bug that prevented project environment builds from being completed successfully.

**What Happened**

The Platform.sh support team began receiving reports of build failures and started an investigation. The issue was quickly identified and a fix was deployed.

**Impact**

Both production and development environments remained available. The impact was that new deployments would fail during the time frame of the incident.
This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.

We're investigating an issue regarding builds failing in the us.platform.sh region.  This does not affect the availability of any production or development sites.

We'll provide updates as we continue our investigation.
